page.title: 01LANDSCAPE - CARTMEL VALLEY
page.content: { { Our 4 x 3km. block is located towards the southern end of the Cartmel Valley,where the various tiny becks and the River Eea converge. The east side of the valley is dominated by Hampsfell - noted for its limestone pavement. Surface water is absent on the fell and a spring line exists at about 200 feet above sea level. The river Eea leaves the valley through a narrow gap by the village of Cark and flows into the north end of Morecambe Bay. The land to the west side of the valley is formed of gently rolling scars and barrows which are heavily wooded with a mixture of coniferous and deciduous plantings. The village of Cartmel itself, in the centre of our study area, is everywhere dominated by the Priory built in 1188.
